Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Transparent Antenna Technology for Next Generation Wireless Consumer Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that it offers low cost, and compact
tablet/mobile devices with better wireless connectivity and increased battery life. Lower cost of these
devices will enable their widespread use in the society and enable use of broadband services with higher
efficiency and better connectivity. The transparent antenna technology offers a platform on which
several other applications can be built. For instance, compact health monitoring sensors can be
integrated with wireless capability by integrating antennas on their displays. This technology also will
also improve wireless capability of wearables as they have very limited real estate for antennas.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop transparent antenna
technology for wireless consumer devices. This SBIR project will advance our understanding of
interactions between touch sensor and transparent antennas and enable development of multifunctional
touch sensors that not only operates as a touch sensor but also a transparent antenna as
well. A very comprehensive research approach will be undertaken in Phase I. Namely, in addition to
evaluating performance of the antenna technology in the presence of touch sensor, performance of
touch sensor in the presence of transparent antennas will also be characterized to ensure that the
proposed multi?]functional touch sensors meet the requirements of wireless consumer devices such as
tablets and mobile phones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses a major need in the consumer wireless devices industry by developing an Antenna on Touch (AoT) technology on touch screens to enable lower cost, and more compact laptop/tablet/mobile devices with better wireless connectivity. The approach taken to achieve this end goal is to first develop a truly transparent antenna with transparent ITO resistive films on glass in the bezel area of a large laptop platform in the presence of all the platform components, like the lossy touch screen and VCOM layer. In this report, we show the measured antenna efficiency in a Satimo anechoic chamber of about 60-70% which is well beyond the minimum OEM specs for such antennas on this platform. 

Next we move on to a smaller and much more challenging and in demand tablet/handset platform in which we extensively use the touch screen view area for the design of transparent LTE and Wi-fi antennas. Two different antenna designs are developed with part of the antenna structure on a Flexible printed circuit(FPC) substrate which also includes the antenna feed and the other part on a thin film on which the transparent  ITO is deposited. This thin film antenna layer forms part of the touch screen layer stackup. In the first design, the antenna layer is above the touch screen layers and in the second, the antenna layer is below the touch screen.  At present the antenna layer has its own FPC, but our future goal is to use the touch layer FPC to feed the antenna. We successfully implemented a 2.1GHz LTE antenna and a 2.4GHz WiFi antenna.
